CONJUGATES: prevail (v.) | prevailed (past t.) | prevails (3rd sing.) | prevalence (n.)
ETYMOLOGY: From Middle English prevailen, from Old French prevaloir, from Latin praevalēre (to be very strong, to have superiority), from prae- (before, very) + valēre (to be strong, be powerful).

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Existing or accepted most widely in a particular area or at a particular time; generally current.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 普遍存在的；盛行的；流行的；主要的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The prevailing mood in the city was one of cautious optimism after the election.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 选举结束后，这座城市普遍的情绪是谨慎乐观。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Having power or influence; proving to be superior in strength or success.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 占优势的；获胜的；有影响力的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He fought hard against the prevailing winds of political change.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他努力抵抗政治变革的强势潮流。

REGISTER: General usage, often found in formal contexts (e.g., 'prevailing wage', 'prevailing views').
